ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti Chatti
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti Chatti
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti Chatti
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti was attentive and gave good comments on the submitted texts.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti Chatti

Instructor: Deepti Chatti  No TAs for this class.

Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti Chatti

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti is a great resource. She has remained highly accessible and eager to help throughout the semester.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  I appreciate the feedback to the weekly assignments, though it came at strange times over the course of the semester. Still, it was appreciated.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  I had very little interaction with the TA
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti gave thoughtful responses to the writing assignments I submitted, and had some good insights during the class lectures- I wish we had heard more from her!

Instructor: Deepti Chatti  She is very accessible and helpful. Her comments in class were very smart and thoughtful, however they should happen more often. When she couldn't help me, she always looked for the Rob's help and gave me a followup. She was also very proactive when offered a Endnote workshop in order to help the students with citation.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti was an excellent TF. She was always available to answer questions and very helpful.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti was very thoughtful, insightful and supportive.

Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti was very approachable and helpful. I visited her a couple times throughout the semester to express concerns about my progress in the course. She heard me out, and helped me come up with an appropriate plan of action.

Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti was great! She always made herself available to student questions and seemed to have a good handle on the course materials. She also held a mini Endnote workshop to help students with citations for our final paper.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti is great. She's responsive and engaged.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Knowledgeable, open, constructive comments on assignments
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Very available and helpful in corresponding and answering questions.
Instructor: Deepti Chatti  She is very knowledgeable and was very helpful with assignments.

Instructor: Deepti Chatti  Deepti was very responsive whenever I approached her with questions and was good to have participate in the student-led discussions. I really appreciate the End Note workshop she led. It would have been nice to have some type of more official lecture from her to better understand her background and perspective relative to climate change.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: It's a shame that this is the last time this course will be offered with Prof. Bailis.
#14: It takes a lot of time and reading (4 weeks or so) to get everyone on the same level of knowledge about the issues. This is necessary, but can bog down the course a bit as well.

While I am very interested in climate change, I had no academic experience with it before this course. Because of the broad scope, this was a great into/overview course. But at the same time, we went into so many aspects of climate change in depth, it seems like an appropriate course for people who already had some background as well. This can be a depressing topic to delve into and seems to have a lot of the most experienced people down, including Rob and Deepti. To counteract that dynamic, but not in a fake way, it would be good to include mini lectures from time to time on what makes the instructors hopeful about the situation... and maybe have the students contribute to this conversation as well.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Very comprehensive overview of the science, institutions, and controversies behind CC
The course provided a broad overview of the climate change issue and provided some strong reading material.

The breadth of ideas covered and the access/direction toward the literature that supports these ideas. Also, the openness of the final paper gives students the chance to select something they find most interesting and really get a thorough understanding of that topic.
It is a good introductory survey course in what has become a very big and complex subject
Interesting material. I appreciated the amount of time spent on adaptation, resilience and vulnerability.

it is a very broad course and covered very diverse aspects of climate change. The course gave the students a general idea of all perspectives that could be considered and discussed in terms of climate change. The professor also offered a huge variety of sources for further research.
I enjoyed the reading materials, the lectures, and the class discussions.

The policy memo and the final paper are really good ways to make students bring together what they've learned in the course and apply it to a potential real-world situation of their interest. I enjoyed writing my memo and the follow-up final paper, which I based on my policy memo.

Great overview. Hard to cover everything in a topic like this, but I think the course did a good job at exposing students to different sides of the problems and potential solutions. Also nearly impossible to meet every students expectations for the course, because some people will want more international negotiations, others will want more theory, and others will want more examinations of sector based national solutions. Overall though I thought the balance was good. I would definitely recommend keeping the adaptation memo, because it makes folks with more of a mitigation mindset think about the other side of the problem.
Assignments, including weekly reading responses, were very good in getting me to sit down and think about the readings and course material in a deeper way.
Some of the readings were very interesting, and I liked when there was a back and forth discussion between the class and Prof. Bailis, instead of Prof. Bailis just going through his slides/lecture.
The breadth of the course was great for people who are new to the field. I also enjoyed writing the papers because I was able to delve into a subject I found interesting.

Twofold: 1) Professor Bailis works to keep the course current, weaving recent news, studies, and events into his lectures. 2) the format of the course - lecture first and discussion activity second - really works.

I loved to get really up-to-date information on both climate science and the UNFCCC negotiations. The graphics on the slides were superb. I also enjoyed the freedom to pick my own topic for the term paper. For someone who is already familiar with climate change policy and science, this was still a great course to take!
Structure of many different aspects of 3 main topics
Readings
Writing the policy memo and final paper were good experiences and will be useful in future endeavors.
The fact that it included a little bit of everything: the basic science, history of international negotiations, adaptation, mitigation, impacts on health, etc.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: A group midterm project or final could complement the course well, given the cooperative nature/challenge of climate change negotiations. The discussions help fulfill this, but a larger project in which students could work together in-depth may be an interesting future option.

- Course focused far too heavily on climate change adaptation and far too little on mitigation and policy. - Course was poorly advertised as it did not significantly address climate issues like policy. - Lectures were counterproductively long. - Some papers seemed quite outdated.

If there was more attention given to the perceptions of climate change, how the media portrays and shares information, and more instruction about how to help educate the general public about the importance of these issues. Also, it would have been interesting to have more controversial ideas discussed and possibly some prescription for ideas.

The last hour of each three hour class was a student let discussion. These were largely unfocused, and did not lead to in depth discussions or learning. The student discussion leaders each week were allowed to pick any discussion topic they wanted, with very little guidance, and were allowed to formulate the teaching exercise any way they wanted. The inexperience of students in creating a good learning experience showed.

I wish we had gone deeper into a lot of the material, rather than simply reviewing the readings. It would have been interesting to do some case studies in class and to discuss the nuances and practicalities of climate change in more detail. I would have liked to have heard some of Professor Bailis' own experiences working internationally.

Rob should focus more on the basics concepts before any other advancement in content. He also should speak slowly and louder. The classroom was very dark and cold, which sometimes affected the learning. The instructor is very knowledgeable and have a notable domain of all topics approached in class. However, as an international student, it was hard to follow the class because speaks very fast and not loud enough to listen. The explanation were also very fast and the load of contents per class were too much.
None, I thought the course was excellent.
Lectures are too long.

People came from a lot of cool backgrounds and had a range of unique perspectives on climate change. Could have been cool to go around and hear from folks in the beginning of the class to get a sense of those backgrounds.

The student led discussions need help. The professor should have intervened to make them more engaging. The professor's lectures were non engaging either. This course had a lot of potential, considering all of the current climate change headlines; however, I did not leave this course feeling like I had a firm grasp in current affairs. The lectures could be improved by searing clear of heady charts and graphs... a few are fine, but the basic concepts and underlining conclusions should be emphasized. I felt very lost and never engaged in this class.

To be honest, I was disappointed with the class overall. I'm interested in a career in climate policy and was most excited about taking this course, but somehow it fell flat for me. For example, during the lecture portion of the class, I did not feel as challenged as I could've been and I do not think there was enough emphasis on exchanges between Prof. Bailis and the students. Prof. Bailis would complete his lecture in about 2 hrs with the final hour used as a discussion/simulation/break into groups led by students each week. I would've wanted Rob to challenge the class to think critically about these difficult issues, and to bring in examples from his experiences in the field. Instead, the lecture felt more like a summary of information (which I found to be very interesting) but it was surface-level, and as a class we didn't go much "deeper." The portion of class for student discussion was likely intended to do so, but after a few weeks the class discussion/activity was pretty similar and felt repetitive. One recommendation would be to hold this class twice a week, to break up the amount of lecture time.
The weekly responses take so much time. For some of the discussions, the amount of reading is daunting. Either requiring less reading or fewer responses would be helpful.
I think Professor Bailis excels most in conversation, making the large-class lecture format tricky for maximum effect. Not sure how to fix this, though.

Rob is very open to discussing subjects with students, but may still be perfecting his lecture style. is lectures tend to be very one-sided with little to no student participation. Rather than the half lecture, half student led discussions (which often felt like a waste of time), I would prefer to have him lecture at a slower pace, stopping to discuss items of interest as the arise. Also Bowers auditorium is a terrible classroom space and is very un-conducive to interaction and discussion.
The group discussions felt somewhat repetitive every week. I would have liked if they were a bit more structured or if they drew more on the readings from the week to actually learn the material.
What I mentioned above... somehow inspiring hope.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: The class time was blocked into a half lecture - half discussion format, with one feeding into the other. The discussions were largely effective in complementing the lecture material.
See answer above

The relationship was very effective, since we had discussions every class and the discussions were based on our readings for the week and the specific topics of our classes. However, I think that we should have discussions sections each two weeks; discussions every week ended up being tiring.
Yes, the lectures and class discussions were well integrated and effective.

The discussion sections seemed tedious by the end. An alternative could be to mix it up with individual or team presentations on chosen climate change topics. Maybe students could have the choice to either lead a discussion related to the readings or make a presentation. Could have also have interspersed student presentations of case studies within the main lectures to break things up a bit.
No lab section.
The discussions were interesting and a nice way to change it up. Sometimes though it was nice to have discussions that popped up during lecture.
Yes, discussion part of the class was very useful.
This varied because different groups of students were in charge each week.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: It's fundamental to anyone interested in international development policy, climate change policy, international justice, or most any environmental issue impacted by CC. This course could arguably be considered a "foundations" course at the Forestry school.
I was seeking an opportunity to deepen my understanding of the climate change issue and instead the course was mainly review. F&ES is significantly short on climate change courses.

Anyone leaving FES with an "environmental management" degree must have at least a basic understanding of the science and politics that surrounds climate change. This course offers just that, as well as the opportunity to delve deeply into a climate issue of the student's choice, which provides valuable time for self-discovery buoyed by an extremely intelligent and knowledgeable professor who is supportive and responsive to student interests and concerns.
This is the only introductory course on climate change, one of my primary interests. It's also one of the only ones that looks at international developing countries.
This course fits well into my program, as I am interested in mitigating the effects of climate change on our natural resources.

This course fits into my interests for climate change. The course is considered for most of the specializations. I originally had planned to pursue the climate change science, adaptation, and mitigation specialization, but it no longer exists.

I do not plan to work within the international climate change arena; however, I think its very important as an environmental manager to know what's going on and be able to talk about climate change in a critical way.

As I'm interested in climate policy, this course is critical to my studies at FES. Given that Rob will be leaving at the end of the academic year, I sincerely hope that FES staff and the administration are working hard to offer future courses in climate change policy. A few students and I met with Dean Crane to discuss this earlier in the semester and it sounds like there is potential to bring in an outside practitioner to teach a course, if all of the logistics align. As the top graduate school for environmental studies, I was surprised that there is not a greater commitment and resources dedicated to preparing students to the growing and important field of climate change policy and mitigation in the U.S.
I'm interested in urban sustainability in developing countries which is closely tied to climate change issues.
Good overview on climate change, incentives to continue reading in most interesting topics.

This is (was) the only course offered at FES on climate change that is practical (i.e. not focusing exclusively on atmospheric chemistry). I intended to focus my studies at FES on climate change, and it's a real shame that this course will not be offered following the decision to deny Professor Bailis tenure. How can FES claim to create global environmental leaders and not offer any courses on climate change?
My research paper helped me identify the effects of climate change on water resources in developing nations which falls in line with my future endeavors.
Since I am focusing on climate change communication, it was critical for me to have more of a background in the science and policy side.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: The information is important for my future work and general knowledge

To provide a baseline of my understanding, and to make sure I knew what I (and everyone else) am talking about when we think of "climate change" 350ppm, 2 degrees C, tipping points, social/environmental justice, geoengineering, and so forth.
It is the basic course in the field I intend to pursue
It's in line with my interests in climate change. I thought Professor Bailis would have some interesting insights, given his research.
To have more knowledge about climate change and be able to carry a discussion about the topic. I also want to work on adaptation to climate change when I finish school.
I wanted to learn more about the impacts of climate change, and the most current adaptation and mitigation practices, which this course taught well.

There are not a lot of climate change courses offered at F&ES (unfortunately and strangely), and I wanted to take this one now in case I could not take it next year. I'm glad I made that decision. The course also counts towards several specializations, in case I wanted to earn any.
Get a holistic view of climate change impacts and potential solutions
Same as above.
I felt like a comprehensive understanding of this topic is vital to an MEM candidate heading into the work force today.
See answers above.
I have never taken a formal climate change mitigation and adaptation class and thought it important.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
No, I had hoped for a greater emphasis on mitigation strategies and climate change policy.

Yes, broadly speaking. I didn't have a set goal, but instead was looking for exposure to a wide range of pertinent concepts and ideas. I got that exposure and gained literacy of a complex global issue.
Medium to high
No. I think the class could have gone into greater detail and depth. Half of each class period was led by small student groups, some of which were more helpful and interesting than others.
I was expecting more, but since we had many readings and the content was so broad, I couldn't retain what was expecting for.
Yes indeed.
No.
Yes

Aside from the readings and slides in class, I learned the most through the two major writing assignments - a policy climate adaptation memo (to a real person on a real issue) and a final paper on the topic of your choice. I thought this part of the course was very useful.
Yes
Yes.
Yes, but I did not expect such a big policy focus.
Yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantages: I worked with a friend, which facilitated our discussions. It was also a great opportunity to practice how to lead a discussion and present a topic to a classroom. Disadvantages: one of the members was not so committed as the other, so the work sharing was not balanced.
It was helpful to work in a group for our leading of the class discussion, as each person brought different ideas and perspectives to examine.
Leading discussion at the end of one of the classes was useful and fun, and some of our discussion components were creative and fun.
More substantial group projects could have been valuable.
Worked on one particular topic and discussed on how to organize a successful discussion.

The group discussions allowed us to think critically about the topics in class. However most classes the discussions felt repetitive as if we were discussing solutions that applied to the other topics in class.
Many of the student-led discussions involved small group activities. It was great to hear the different perspectives on the issues in those small groups.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Find a time-machine.
This course is only appropriate for students with little to no background in climate change.

There is a lot to read, but it isn't overwhelming. Most of the content is popular enough to have been covered by many authors so there is potential to augment the content assigned in this way. Come prepared to class and be willing to engage with the professor and your classmates. The more involved you are in this course and the more involved you get in the discussion sessions, the greater the value this course will have.
In my opinion, every student at F&ES should take this course.
This class will not be offered again, so N/A. I hope that this gap is filled by another professor.
Take it if you have time to read all the texts and are interested in working with climate change after school.
I would advise them to read the supplemental materials as well, as all of the readings are quite relevant, cutting-edge resources.
Very good class for if you want to go into policy! You should take it!
Think carefully about whether the professor's teaching style fits with your learning preferences.
Wish they could take it with Bailis.

As far as I know, this course will not be offered next year. I hope something similar to it is offered to incoming students and I would recommend students take a climate policy course with a writing component.
If you're interested, take it now, because it won't be offered for much longer!
Focus on the assigned readings
Take the course... it's a great overview of the topic. If it's just one long afternoon lecture per week, bring caffeine or some other way to help stay engaged.
